overview: This subject provides advanced critical appraisal of contemporary and controversial issues in the biosciences and, for some, how they may inform solutions to anthropogenic challenges. Topics are drawn from physiology, plant and microbial sciences, cellular and developmental genetics, ecology and evolutionary biology. Each week, students (in groups of 2-3) will provide a seminar of a particular issue (reflecting a fundamental idea or a controversy of competing ideas or empirical evidence), which will form the basis of subsequent critical discussion by the class. Students will attend 12 seminars, at least two will be common to all students, who will then choose from two concurrent series according to their research interests. The choice of specific issues within each series will be determined at the start of the subject according to the availability of individual academic staff that act as a ‘champion’ of the issue.

assessments.description: Seminar presentations: each week on a single topic, comprising a group (2-3 students) presentation (20-30 mins), then individual presentations (15 mins). 40 minutes
Written work: 'wiki-style' summary of the oral presentation, prepared by the group. 1000 words
Written work: three peer reviews. 1000 words (each)
assessments.timing: Two reviews due during the teaching period and the final review due during the assessment period

assessments.description: Participation: social annotation of published papers using the Perusall platform, 50-100 words each week. 50-100 words (each)
Participation: quantity and quality of oral commentary during class

Semester 1.Contact hours: 30 contact hours comprising one 2.5-hour seminar per week.

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.

Subject notes: Students undertaking this subject will be expected to regularly access an internet-enabled computer.
Related Handbook entries: This subject contributes to the following:
Available to Study Abroad and/or Study E: This subject is available to students studying at the University from eligible overseas institutions on exchange and study abroad. Students are required to satisfy any listed requirements, such as pre- and co-requisites, for enrolment in the subject.
